metadata.case_name: Ramnagar Cane Sugar Co. Ltd. v. Respondents

facts.text: Appellant Ramnagar Cane Sugar Co. Ltd. incorporated under Indian Companies Act, manufactures sugar at factory in Plassey, Nadia district, declared public utility service by notification on October 8, 1953.
Appellant employs about 545 permanent men and 703 seasonal men excluding casual labourers.
Majority of workmen belong to Ramnagar Cane Sugar Co. Employees Union (Employees Union); minority to Ramnagar Sugar Mill Workers Union (Workers Union). Respondents belong to Workers Union.
Workers Union presented charter of demands to appellant on December 9, 1953.
Employees Union presented similar charter of demands on January 20, 1954.
Workers Union served notice of strike on appellant on January 20, 1954.
Meeting held before Conciliation Officer on February 1, 1954, attended by Employees Union and appellant; notice served on Workers Union.
On February 2, 1954, appellant suggested separate discussions with two unions to Conciliation Officer; Workers Union objected and informed Conciliation Officer that conciliation had failed.
Conciliation Officer sent failure report under s.12(4) of Industrial Disputes Act to Workers Union only on February 3, 1954.
Appellant and Employees Union arrived at settlement on February 25, 1954, recorded in memo signed by both parties.
Workers Union commenced strike on February 13, 1954.

Criminal complaint filed against eleven respondents under s.11 West Bengal Security Act, 1950; charge: on or about February 13, 1954, committed subversive acts impeding work of public utility concern producing essential commodity sugar.
Respondents pleaded not guilty, arguing strike was not illegal.
Magistrate, First Class at Krishnagar, Nadia, acquitted respondents on August 3, 1956 in G.R. Case No.69 of 1954, holding strike not illegal.
Appellant filed revision in Calcutta High Court (Criminal Revision No.1577 of 1956); High Court dismissed on August 19, 1957, holding strike not illegal.
Appellant applied for certificate to High Court, dismissed; obtained special leave from Supreme Court.
Charters of demands by both unions cover all employees of appellant, not specific sections; settlement benefited members of both unions.

legal_issues.text: Whether the strike commenced by Workers Union on February 13, 1954, was illegal under s.24 read with s.22(1)(d) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, given pendency of conciliation proceedings between appellant and Employees Union.

petitioner_arguments.text: Conciliation proceedings with Employees Union continued until February 25, 1954, when settlement arrived; pendency thereof makes strike by respondents illegal under s.22(1)(d) as it binds all workmen.

respondent_arguments.text: Conciliation proceedings with Workers Union ended on February 2, 1954, failure report sent February 3, 1954; no conciliation pending between Workers Union/respondents and appellant after February 3.
Respondents do not belong to Employees Union, so conciliation with Employees Union does not bind them or make strike illegal.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of Industrial Disputes Act: Industrial dispute raised by one union binds all workmen under s.18(3)(d); settlement in conciliation binds all employees in establishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pendency of conciliation with one union on common demands bars strike by all employees in public utility service under s.22(1)(d).

court_reasoning.text: Demands in charters by both unions cover all employees, not limited sections; settlement benefited all including Workers Union members.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts below erred in narrow construction of s.22(1)(d); strike illegal as conciliation pending with Employees Union.

court_reasoning.text: Illegal strike constitutes subversive act under s.2(9)(e) Explanation II, West Bengal Security Act, punishable under s.11.

holdings.text: Pendency of conciliation proceedings between employer and one union on demands concerning all employees bars strike by employees of rival union under s.22(1)(d) in public utility service.
Strike on February 13, 1954, illegal under s.24; constitutes subversive act under West Bengal Security Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Associated Cement Companies Ltd., Porbandar v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar questions under s.19(6) and s.33(1)(a) of Industrial Disputes Act

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. New India Motors P. Ltd. v. K. T. Morris
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar questions under s.19(6) and s.33(1)(a) of Industrial Disputes Act

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines illegal strike; binding nature of conciliation settlements on all workmen; bar on strike during pendency of conciliation in public utility service

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Security Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Punishes subversive acts; illegal strike not in furtherance of industrial dispute, constitutes subversive act impeding essential commodity production

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of acquittal by Magistrate and Calcutta High Court set aside; respondents convicted of offence under s.11 West Bengal Security Act. Appellant not pressing for heavy sentence, sought decision on construction of s.22(1)(d) Industrial Disputes Act.
outcome.relief_granted: Conviction of respondents; no specific sentence emphasized

key_quotes.text: "the pendency of the conciliation proceedings between the appellant and the Employees Union attracts the provisions of s.22(1)(d) to the strike in question and makes the said strike illegal under s.24(1) of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on illegality of strike

key_quotes.text: "a settlement arrived at in the course of conciliation proceedings which has become enforceable shall be binding on all the parties specified in cls.(a),(b),(c) and (d) of sub-s.(3)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains binding effect under s.18(3) on all workmen
